The movie so misunderstood
Authors synopsis - "High speed's and thrilling bumper to bumper sequences aren't the only things this movie has to offer. With it's touching bromance and charismatic characters Ford v Ferrari is an homage to the truly great Hollywood films of old, as it brings to life a great cinematic representation of one of racings most historical events and truly becomes a must see for everyone."

On the surface, Ford v Ferrari is portrayed as a touch and go film for motoring enthusiasts, but after seeing the film that couldn't be further from the truth. Director James Mangold who's name is widely appreciated after films such as Logan and 3:10 to Yuma has really proven to the audience racing films are no longer just for a certain audience, but can be enjoyed by all in this exhilarating biopic. The movie really stands out through its main characters' bromance between Carroll Shelby and Ken Miles played by Matt Damon and Christian Bale, delivering some of their best acting yet. 

The movie opens up with Matt Damon's Carroll Shelby winning the grueling 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1959 for the Aston Martin team before explaining that the victory was short-lived, as Shelby's racing career comes to an end due to heart complications. After being forced into retirement Shelby focusses on his vehicle design and sales career whilst at the same time the audience is introduced to the big boss of Ford: Henry Ford II played tremendously by Tracy Letts. This scene sets up the entire drive of the film as the big boss explains to all of his working staff that ford is coming to an end at the hands of bad business and poor vehicle manufacturing leading to Fords diminishing reputation. From here the movie kicks into gear as the idea of buying out Ferrari runs across Henry Ford from the marketing man Lee Lacocca (Jon Bernthal), but goes south and a rivalry is born as Ford wishes to beat Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone) at his own game. At the 24 hours of Le Mans, which Ferrari has dominated over the years.

Matt Damon produces one of his best performances throughout his acting career within this film. Showing the audience a very likable, charismatic and enthusiastic Carroll Shelby who will stop at nothing to overcome the challenge laid out to him by ford. Another nice addition to this film is Ken Miles' wife Molly (Caitriona Balfe), who stands out as a badass in her own right as she knows what makes Ken really shiver in his boots, and in one great scene really makes the soon to be famous racing driver crap his pants. This movie holds a plethora of great characters and fantastic acting that will definitely have the academy keep a keen eye out heading forward towards the Oscars.

Another fantastic outline within this film is its score composed by Marco Beltrami and Buck Sanders which really captures the feeling of racing, from the intense drumming and guitar riffs to the loud trumpets of victory the score doesn't feel the slightest out of place as it sticks to the instrumentals that you would find in such a time period. 

As much as this film is great there are some flaws that audience members will definitely take away with them. One glaring flaw is this films run time clocking in at two hours and thirty-two minutes. The film at some instances does feel like it begins to drag on a little, but this does thankfully become resolved as once the boredom begins to settle in it shoots back up to a thrilling pace which does seem to be great, but maybe a cutback on some of the more slower scenes would really help this film shine more within the audience. Another glaring flaw I noticed wasn't necessarily the movie itself, but it's marketing. The marketing seems to highlight one thing and one thing alone, and that is it's a car film. I understand yes it is essentially a car-based film, but it is also so much more with a great narrative about true success and fighting for a goal as well as just what it means to show fantastic sportsmanship. However, most of these highlights within the film are overshadowed within the trailers and previews with just racing which leads to only one certain audience really discussing this film, that audience being motor enthusiasts when in reality this movie is for everyone.

And finally, we come to the verdict of this film. As much as I enjoy this film I understand that people have differing opinions so instead of giving out a solid number out of ten I will leave a quick overview so you can decide whether to see the film for yourself. This is a high stake sports film with intense scenes and loveable characters that show great development as the story goes on. The film has an enigmatic score and really captures the feeling of racing in the 60's that really puts you on the edge of your seat as the characters resonate with the audience making this experience something amazing.

Excellent movie, the best so far this year. I love a film that tells a story about this amazing human drama in history that you never new was playing out in people’s lives. This film had a great script, excellent, Oscar worthy performances by a hugely talented cast, and a gut wrenching and wonderful depiction of human relationships and how they impact the world around them. The racing sequences were astounding. I’m a sixty year old woman, and I am a sports fan, but never a big fan of racing. The human drama contained within the pursuit of mechanical perfection was riveting. But of course, it wasn’t the mechanical and the engineering that made the difference. It was a legendary driver and an automobile designer, and the people around them which makes this film so compelling. On the edge of my seat, and with a tissue to my eyes, this was a brilliant film from start to finish line.

Mangold's new film is Hollywood fun in the best way possible, reminding me a lot of Catch Me If You Can in that it is so well made, well acted, and entertaining all at once. The two main strengths of the film are the leads and the driving scenes. Bale and Damon have such great chemistry and bounce off each other in different ways. Sometimes they're fighting and sometimes they're collaborating, but it's never uninteresting. And then there are the driving scenes. They are filmed with so much energy and clarity, that it's never confusing or overwhelming in a bad way. It's overwhelming in terms of volume and stakes; the racing scenes have such an intensity that I had two moments where I couldn't breathe and then I finally released. However, there are some moments that are very Hollywood. Bits of dialogue that come off as very cliché. Yet, it never gets in the way of the fun to be had.

An unconventional (and true!) David and Goliath story, where the underdog is the Ford Motor Company, which, despite massive financial resources, struggles in vain to have their sports car racing team dethrone Ferrari at the 24 Hours of Le Mans race in the late 1950s/early 1960s. Enter legendary racer and sports car builder Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) who has a plan to win with  Ford hardware. One problem? He needs his friend, the "difficult" but brilliant driver and engineer Ken Miles (Christian Bale, disappearing into another wonderful character) to pull it off, despite some hardcore resistance from Ford's executives. The movie works because we care about this friendship, and get involved in the stresses it's put under. And the racing scenes are exhilarating. Recommended.

***Spoiler-Free Commentary*** Ford V Ferrari, surprisingly, devoted a substantial amount of nuanced thought on class and Respectability Politics than I had anticipated going in. It was refreshing to see. The film has so much more to say than, 'Carroll Shelby (Damon) was a great contributor to the Ford badge racing legacy' or that 'racing is a sport that's still relevant today despite the push away from fossil fuels.' I can't say I much cared about either prior to watching the mid-60s biopic/drama based on real events. But that the film managed to spark a little combustion of interest (pardon the pun) in me about the sport and its history in addition to relatively unknown motorsport legend and WWII Vet, Ken Miles (Bale), I think speaks volumes. In short, You need not be a gearhead racerboy/ hot-rod guy to apprciate the film. In fact, Hollywood needs to make more quality, old-school films about regular people, just like this. No silly alternative-reality Tarantino cynicism for this guy here. I much prefer reality to his (oddly popular) predilection for fetishism (yes, that is a dig at his latest film which was horribly, horribly overrated). Lastly, for a film that has so much more to say than gratuitous roaring V8 exhaust notes, of which it has no shortage of, I think You'd be hard-pressed to choose a better Thanksgiving movie to watch with family this week than the 3:10 to Yuma Director's latest feature. I was not expecting the emotional involvement in the real-life characters we were delivered in this polished, finished product of a film. Bravo 👏👏👏 to the creative team who brought this incredibly relatable story to Life; and indeed, to those who actually lived it. 👍👍

Ford v Ferrari(2019) REVIEW 
By: James Eversole Jr.

    James Mangold crafts another fine film to his resume with Matt Damon and Christian Bale at the lead giving fantastic performances and I am not shocked at all they are both up for Oscar consideration because they both were just fantastic.
    The writing and Directing was well done in the ability to tell this iconic story for hardcore car/race fans and also at the same time making it easy for people who know nothing about cars(me 😂🤣) to follow along with the car science at hand and what the characters are trying accomplish in the film. The movie is also more then just a racing movie and brings a emotional story of love, friendship and family. November 15, 2019

As a sports drama, "Ford v Ferrari" is more interesting and informative than emotional and compelling, which is fine, because interesting and informative make the movie just as watchable. The way it handles its genre's usual plot and character developments isn't exactly inspired, but it does excel in the areas where it probably matters most given the subject matter, and that's in the car and racing sequences. They are energetic and convincing without being deafening or over-the-top. These, combined with a particularly notable performance from Christian Bale, add up to an overall solid cinematic experience and, I'm assuming, a mostly accurate representation of a touchstone moment in motorsports history. 

Based on an original screenplay by Jez and John-Henry Butterworth and Jason Keller, "Ford v Ferrari" chronicles the Ford Motor Company's years-long quest to win the 1966 Le Mans sports race and ultimately steal the crown from reigning Ferrari, which had captured the title for the past six years. For the prideful old boys' club members of Ford, winning Le Mans was personal after Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone) refused a 1963 takeover deal from Ford's Lee Iacocca (John Bernthal) and, according to the movie, said, "Ford makes ugly little cars in ugly factories." He allegedly also called Ford's CEO, Henry Ford II (Tracy Letts), "fat."

Refusing to go down without a fight, Ford enlists former race car driver and one-time Le Mans champion Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) to "go to war" and oversee the engineering of a new Ford vehicle that would not only break speed records but also guarantee victory. It's Shelby's personal story that actually opens the film. We see him drift and lose focus during his last race, after which he's forced into early retirement when doctors tell him he has an unstable heart condition.

Since then, Shelby heads a small, Los Angeles-based racing team, which includes the heavy-British-accented Ken Miles (Bale), who loves racing but mostly does it as a side gig while trying to keep his mechanic's garage afloat. Mollie (Caitriona Balfe) is Ken's dedicated and level-headed wife and Peter (Noah Jupe) his enthusiastic, curious son. They stand by Ken through thick and thin as the once unbelievable idea of racing Le Mans slowly becomes a reality.

Following a rather routine setup, "Ford v Ferrari" starts to gain traction around the one-third mark when it begins to enlighten us on all the planning, testing, mechanics, logistics, etc. that go into designing and building a car, details the movie not only makes coherent but also fascinating, especially when it comes to a race car, the parts of which need to be taken off and replaced at any given moment and where factors such as weight and the type of metal play a very crucial part. We witness all the trials and errors Shelby and Miles' crew endures, including unexpected malfunctions and near-fatal crashes, not to mention the corporate bureaucracy looming over their endeavor, particularly from Leo Beebe (Josh Lucas), Ford's brownnosing senior executive VP, who thinks Miles should be replaced by a more experienced driver. 

Director James Mangold ("Walk the Line," "Logan") presents this story mostly linearly, and as one conflict plays out after another, eventually culminating in Ford unleashing its GT40 model at Le Mans, the movie has an air of "then this happened, then this happened…" It's this safe and straightforward approach to the material that keeps our emotional investment in the events somewhat at bay, because even though the characters are down-to-earth, likable and vulnerable, the machinations of the genre overshadow the potential drama and limit the number of would-be surprises. In the back of our minds, we know "Ford v Ferrari" is more or less a standard underdog tale, one that's based on an "incredible true story" no less, and so we have a pretty good idea of how it's going to turn out (and if you're already aware of the history of the actual 1966 Le Mans race, then you know for certain). We also know, given the genre, that as the heroes prepare for the race, they will have to overcome the usual hurdles, growing pains, close-calls and run-ins with "villains" that characterize so many movies of this type.

That being said, Mangold and his team avoid letting the inevitabilities of the genre stall the movie's momentum or limit its appeal. They seem so captivated by the pure science and possibilities of auto engineering and the stalwart determination of the characters that their enthusiasm spreads to us. Even though I watched "Ford v Ferrari" mostly objectively and more as a history lesson and tutorial on sports car endurance racing (Le Mans is actually 24 hours long, which I didn't know) than as an involving narrative, the details embedded in the script are engrossing just the same. Despite its two-and-a-half-hour runtime, the movie never wavers as we bear witness to the constant physical, mechanical and political battles being fought up to and on race day. We walk away from it having gained a real sense of what auto racing is like.

Much of this is owed to the film's superb cinematography, special effects, sound and stunts, which blend seamlessly and are rich, vibrant and believable. They don't necessarily feel  overwhelming (like, say, a "Fast and the Furious" movie) but still place us in what feels like the real race car driving world. They make "Ford v Ferrari" exhilarating at times.

As I mentioned, one dramatic quality that should be especially recognized is Christian Bale's performance. How accurately Bale resembles or mimics the real Ken Miles is beside the point; what matters is that he creates an original, genuine, and multi-faceted character we truly believe in, root for, and with whom we empathize. Miles is such a force and beacon of hope and positivity on-screen that it's just a pleasure to watch him do his thing, whether it's compromising with his wife, encouraging his son, or self-reflecting before, during and after a race. There's something very real about him and as I watched Bale disappear into the role, I had to remind myself this was the same actor who played Laurie in "Little Women," Patrick Bateman in "American Psycho,"  Dicky Eklund in "The Fighter," and Batman/Bruce Wayne in "The Dark Knight" movies. The man has range and he reminds of that here.
 
Even though "Ford v Ferrari" didn't move me as much as I would have liked, there's something to be said for what it taught me, and I'm willing to bet more ardent fans of race car driving will find it works on several emotional levels. In fact, this movie seems to have been made for them. It takes the art, craft and skills of race car driving seriously and shows us just how much goes into it and gets us to really think about the minutiae that could either plague or aid racing teams. The movie may not have held heart's attention to the greatest effect, but it certainly held my mind's.

This very interesting movie gets a solid 4 Icees from this reviewer.  The movie, based on true facts (of course with some poetic license, but not much) has people talking about awards.  I don't know about all that, but I did find the movie interesting throughout.

I had no knowledge about the 24 Hours of Le Mans 1966 prior to this movie, but did do some reading afterwards and with the exception of a few details, the movie seems to be pretty much on point.  Matt Damon (aka Jason Bourne) and Christian Bale (aka Batman) both give convincing performances as the main two characters.

The movie at 2.5hrs is a bit long, and slow in spots, but it makes up for it with some good driving scenes, including carnage (get it?  car-nage) during the Le Mans race. The chemistry between the two main characters is believable, as is the corporate image of Ford as portrayed throughout the movie.  Another admirable performance is given by Caitriona Balfe as Mollie Miles and I liked how the movie explored their relationship.  An "acceptable" performance given by Noah Jupe as their son Peter, with solid support by Jon Bernthal (The Punisher) as Lee Iococca and Tracy Letts as Henry Ford II.

I thought the character development was pretty good.  They gave us just enough without going too long to give us the backstories on the primary characters and the situation that led to Ford wanting to get into Le Mans racing. Overall, this is a good movie, period.

As there are many choices during this T-day timeframe, I get it if this doesn't rise to the top of your list, but if you don't see it in the theaters, I definitely recommend you watch it when it comes out on video.

Non-Sports Car Racing Fans:

Unless you hate all autosport, you will at least give this movie 3 out of 5 stars, if not more. Beyond it being the story about the men, not the machine, it's the story about the politics of the production-centric American Automotive Industry.  This is where the US is really different than Europe, and why only a Texan -- the only American (at the time) to win the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the world's oldest running endurance sports car race -- could help Ford win.

And that Texan knew the British (who really are under-represented) were key, and Miles was the engineer and driver who they needed in the seat.


Racing (but non-Endurance Sports Car) Fans:  

You may or may know know Sports Car, especially Endurance Sports Car Racing, between US popular NASCAR and European popular Formula 1.  But don't expect this movie to teach you anything.  At most, you'll get an intro into why Ford and others don't do it in the US, and no one did until the late '90s (first Dodge, then GM after Dodge).

Beyond that, it's a classic intro into -- again -- the foci and politics of the production-centric American Automotive industry.  It's really at the heart of why Ford have such inertia that is difficult to overcome, executives who make every project about themselves, etc...   Even when they have the direction to do something, they shoot themselves in the foot.

This movie is about the men, Shelby and Miles.  It should have been called Ford v. Shelby-Miles   It's almost 2 hours and 20 minutes, but you're lucky it's not longer.  They cut out so much and leave things unexplained that those who already know endurance autosport will instantly recognize.

E.g., it could easily be over 3 hours with explanations, let alone had they included all 3 races of the Endurance Sports Car "Triple Crown" -- Daytona 24 (Feb '66), Sebring 12 (Mar '66) and Le Mans 24 (Jun '66), which is key to the fully story of Miles in 1966.


Endurance Sports Car Racing Fans:  

You will love this movie, with one exception ... no 1966 12 Hours of Sebring (yeah, they left out that exciting finish.  Since it's not in the movie, I'm not spoiling it -- yeah, running out of gas on the last lap? That's a Sebring tradition that still happens!  And while the 1996 24 Hours of Daytona, it is definitely all about its European Title, "Le Mans '66."

The movie doesn't spend it's time explaining things like Triple Crown of Endurance Racing or the ACO-FIA sanction-classifications.  While that would be cool, along with Sebring '66, it would be 3 hours.  Yes, we'd love it if it was, but not everyone else.  So put those things aside.  Also, you will hear no references to the GT40 iterations, and the models are limited to the Mk I and II, with the 'J' at the very end.

That all said, the 'attention to detail' is extremely good.

E.g., you'll recognize the Mk II and even the J at the end.  You'll see how Le Mans looked in the mid '60s and so many other things.  Yes, there are liberties taken, and things missed ... but it's still fun to see them . Because they won't explain things.

So many things are 'glossed over' or 'mentioned in passing,' without explanation, but we know them.

E.g., Damon (who acting I'm not normally fond of) starts by stating Le Mans is 'country roads' and other things that really just 'delivery the spirit' of endurance racing.  Damon also uses phrases like he's Carol, he clearly did his homework.

They really come off like genuine constructors, engineers and drivers, end-to-end.  The dynamics between Miles-Shelby is just going to bring a smile to your face, even if it's not perfect, and you don't really care for Damon (I didn't).  That's what absolutely impressed me.

Maybe others will differ on that point, and I'm not a constructor, let alone driver, myself (just an engineer in another field), but it's really outstanding to see such come out of Hollywood.   See it.

I can count on 1 finger how many racing car movies I have seen and though I may recall who was in them I don't remember any of them and, sadly, because I had heard good things about "Ford v Ferrari" it will probably be in the same category. Based on a true story, the screen writers Jez Butterworth, John-Henry Butterworth and Jason Keller, juggle 4-5 different stories to add human drama to the film while eliminating any one of them would have brought the movie in at a reasonable showing time, way less than the 2 hours and 30 minutes it runs.

At the same time the director James Mangold has one too many race scenes, one too many shots of a foot hitting the brakes, more shots than necessary to prove Ken Myles is eccentric or business owners and their employees can be  underhanded and ruthless.

 Caitriona Balfe, though a bit difficult to understand, impressed me playing the wife of Christian Bale, who as driver Ken Myles, has been getting raves for his role, left me cold and also hard to understand. Matt Damon is, as always, impressive in a strong, somewhat silent way, as former champion driver and now designer of race cars. Tracy Letts in the role of Henry Ford II has a 2 minute moving and at the same time funny scene while being solid in the rest of the film. Josh  Lucas as the boss's right hand man is an effective villain even if the role is a bit overwritten and obvious.

The banter between Damon and Bale tells a lot about both men but one segment, meant to be funny is only funny due to the reaction of Balfe while Bale's scenes with Noah Jupe, just right as his son, shows the man to be a good father.

The behind the scenes of business life certainly isn't new but the behind the scenes of the racing sport and business aspect of it and car companies is interesting.

Though you may know who the winner is, or will be, in "Ford v Ferrari" it will entertain you if you can get through the 30 to 40 minutes unnecessary segments.

In 1966, Ford wanted to jazz up its brand, so they entered the 24 Hours of Le Mans to take on the historically dominant winner, Ferrari. Matt Damon plays the sports car designer who teams up with a famous driver (Christian Bale) for the titular challenge. This film is less about driving and more about the team's drive to win, including the technical challenges and the duo's head-to-head combat with the management of Ford. Most of the racing is saved for the big event, which is masterfully captured and downright riveting. The leads create a compelling duo, but the entire cast is makes this movie work. Director James Mangold keeps the dialogue and conflicts involving, while expanding their personal lives to give extra heft to the drama. A smart and compelling look at hard competition and the will to win.

I saw the movie today with a friend who is a big racing fan - stays up all night watching F1 races, etc., and we both felt this was an excellent movie - an excellent racing movie. 

Further, the historical component of what went on behind the scenes during this important era in Le Mans' history is particularly interesting. Most of us turn on the TV and watch a race with no real understanding of the background politics and posturing that soil auto racing, and this movie gives a lot of insight in that regard. 

The characters in the film are interesting and easy to appreciate. The acting is excellent on every level. The portrayals of well-known historical characters are extremely well done, with details such as period-correct accurate wrist watches and clothing expertly done.

If I were to pose one criticism of the film it would be with CGI and kit cars replacing the legitimate 1966 fleet that raced at Le Mans, but given that many of the original cars now fetch prices around $30 million, it is easy to understand how we come to have race sequences using non-original vehicles. The only car in the film I am certain was a real car from the 1960s is the Shelby Cobra driven by Shelby (Matt Damon) in non-race scenes. 

This is a great racing film, far superior to Le Mans with Steve McQueen, and I feel it would appeal to both racing and non-racing fans alike. The human stories woven into the racing excitement are not superficial at all. 

So, great acting, good racing scenes, excellent historical documentation and a statement about the strength of friendships and their meaning in our lives.

I'm not a huge racing fan. When I suggested to my wife that we see Ford v Ferrari she said, 'I thought you didn't like racing.' Actually, I do not like NASCAR. ('Rednecks turning left', 'NeckCar'.) I do like watching F1, CART, and Grand Prix (and motorcycles), though I haven't watched a race in years. I currently have an MGB, and I used to have a Porsche 911SC. I like cars.

We went to see Ford v Ferrari Saturday afternoon. I went for the cars, and I think that my wife went because she likes Christian Bale and Matt Damon. She also tends to like true stories. We both enjoyed it. She enjoyed it so much, she spent the rest of the evening reading about the competition, Carroll Shelby, Ken Miles, and others online. Many names were familiar to us. My wife wondered how many of the young people in the audience knew who Lee Iacocca was.

Early in the film I whispered to her, 'That looks like Willow Springs.' See, we used to live in the Antelope Valley and I'd been to motorcycle races there.  Not being a HUGE racing fan, all I knew about Le Mans 1966 was that Ford fielded a car that finally beat Ferrari. I didn't know the backstory. In the film, I assumed that Willow Springs Raceway was standing in, in a generic manner, for some other track. Moments after I whispered my comment to my wife, they said it was Willow Springs in the film. That was pretty cool both that they filmed the scenes where we used to live, and that some racing history really was made there.

During the climactic race, I was surprised to see a Porsche 911. There really was a 911 in the race, a private entry by a French driver, number 35. (Porsche entered the 906.)

Of course I picked out the '70s-model Cessna Skyhawk at Santa Monica Airport. It was just there, in the background and out of focus. It had nothing to do with the movie, but... Pilot.

The film had several chuckles. There was the 'NASCAR turning left' put-down, the aftermath of the wrench-throwing scene, and others. Both of us liked the scene where Ken Miles's wife started driving their station wagon like a race car. 

I need more coffee, so I'll just say that Ford v Ferrari is a thoroughly enjoyable show. Good movie. Nice cars.

It was a compelling story with two antagonists. Spoilers ahead

Characters
The primary villain who constantly put obstacles in our heroes' path was Leo Beebe and Josh Lucas knocked this performance out of the park. Very Mad Money marketing is power and he who controls the narrative controls the world.

Enzo Ferrari was a limited antagonist and only stood in the way of Ford Motor. He created an interesting dynamic. There were two conflicts running parallel. 

Jon Bernthal as Lee Iacocca played the bridge between corporate responsibilities and artistic integrity brilliantly, though he was the only suit to show any empathy he was also the only suit you wanted to cheer for and ultimately showed the intransigent nature of corporate committees always win. 

Carroll Shelby played by Matt Damon was a charismatic former driving star searching for his purpose in life once his passion was taken away from him. Damon balances ego and humility perfectly making just enough mistakes to keep the hero flawed yet easy to cheer for.

Christian Bale as Ken Miles gave me flashbacks of the Fighter though Ken's drug of choice was adrenaline. He played the foil to the smart suits at Ford's headquarters brilliantly and put it on full display during his interactions with Lucas and other authority figures. 

Plot
the plot is based on the true story of Ford's failed attempt to acquire Ferrari and their subsequent investment in a racing program headed by Carroll Shelby with Ken Miles as his choice for their lead driver. 

Storytelling
This was the fastest 2.5 hour movie I've sat through. It introduced its three main characters off the bat: Carroll Shelby, Ken Miles, Lee Iaccoca and their immediate struggles. Each fails early and uses it as an opportunity to springboard towards a mutual goal of tackling Ferrari. The constant fight between corporate greed vs integrity of art (because in this movie racing is painted equally as an art and a sport) is the primary theme and fuel for the conflict. A conflict that is impossible to overcome. A conflict that is ultimately won by the villain.

That being said, the supporting characters are quite shallow and portrayed in black and white versions, while also often being historically inaccurate. This division from actual historical facts spans the whole movie, and is in my opinion goes way beyond "creative liberties".
Also, the racing scenes are poorly written, although the camera work and music are very good. These scenes seem to be copied from Fast and Furious books - a lot of rev counters, pedal close ups, ominous stares exchanged at high speeds... It just doesn't work that way. Nobody presses the accelerator at the middle of the strait - it's already pressed to the floor by then. If you want to show pedals in a movie, go for some heel and toe action in the corners, not straight line accelerator pedal work - I almost expected Jeremy Clarkson to be shouting POWEEER...

Do you remember a time when movies were fun? The rush of excitement during the film's climax, the bitter-sweet tears of an emotional conclusion, the laughs of a well-setup joke? You get out of your seat, use the bathroom, get to your car, and talk endlessly with your movie-mate about all the great things you just watched? That's what I experienced this last weekend at the Ford v Ferrari IMAX showing. 

Ford v Ferrari is directed by James Mangold (Walk the Line, Logan), and it stars Matt Damon (Bourne Series) and Christian Bale (Dark Knight series). The film is based on the real story of the Ford Motor Company, headed by Henry Ford II, looking to beat the sales of the seemingly unstoppable General Motors. He tells his workers to come to him with an idea, or don't come back to work. Ford's Marketing Manager Lee Iacocca, played by Jon Bernthal (Netflix's Punisher, The Walking Dead), says that sales are determined by which company wins the biggest races. His idea? To beat the unbeatable Ferrari in the biggest race in the world, The 24 Hours of Le Mans. Iacocca enlists one of the only Americans to win the race, Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon), to build him a car. Shelby tells Iacocca that it takes more than speed; it takes a good driver. Shelby then recruits his longtime racing associate Ken Miles (Christian Bale) to help build and test the car for him since Shelby can't race due to health reasons. What follows is a battle of science, speed, and corporate intervention where all roads lead to the 24 Hour endurance test at Le Mans. Will Shelby risk his entire livelihood on one driver, and will Miles prove his worth to his family and the world?

What I immediately loved about this movie is its cinematography. It looks, sounds, and feels like a 1960's garage. You can practically smell the oil and grease. I'm not necessarily a car guy. I love a beautiful car like any other person, and the revving of an engine is awesome, but I don't care what type of engine it is or what shape of headlight came with what model. What might turn a few people away is the almost three-hour run time. Did I have to take multiple restroom breaks? Yes. Did the movie feel like three hours? No. The fast-paced dialogue and action set a nice pace that never felt like a chore to sit through. 

We sat down dead center in the IMAX Theater, popcorn and sodas in hand. From the opening logos, you hear the roaring of engines, and then a hard cut of a first person perspective of a car zooming down a dark rain-covered road with headlights illuminating only a few feet ahead. Immediately I was blown away by the loud rich sound of the IMAX speakers putting you into the driver's seat. Every time an engine revved and a tire screeched, it was glorious and made your heart race. For the sound design alone, this is a must-own. But what makes this movie unique from others in its genre is the characters and realism. Movies like the Fast and the Furious series focus on spectacle and explosions, hot girls, exotic cars, contemporary music. Ford v Ferrari uses visual and audio aesthetics of 1960's America to place you in that time period without using tired conventional methods (Rolling Stones music anyone?). There's almost no 60's music here, only original score, which works in the movie's favor. Too many times do we see period movies focus too much on reminding you which era you're in instead of just telling the story. Thankfully, Mangold is a great storyteller.

What really stands out here is the acting. Everyone here nails their performance. The standout being Bale as Miles. Once again he transformed his body after gaining a ton of weight to play Dick Cheney in Vice, and lost it all to play Miles. He claims he's done doing that, but we'll have to see. His relationship with the Ford Corporation and his wife and kid are what tug on your heartstrings. He's so likable all you want is to see him succeed. His pure passion for driving is what brings this movie its fun factor.  He perfectly plays off of Damon's dry southern humor and you can tell Miles loves cars and speed. All he wants is to prove he's the one to win Le Mans. Damon does a great job portraying Shelby, and his arc is the one that drives the relationship between Miles and the suites at Ford.

You don't have to be a car nut to enjoy this film. Same reason you don't have to be a chef to love the taste of fine dining. It has fun with the source material and leaves you with a smile on your face during the credits. I think the standout here is Bale and awards will surely be coming his way. Is it a little long? Sure, but you're so enthralled with the action that you never think about looking at your watch.

Carroll Shelby was the only American to win Le Mans by 1959 after which he had to retire from racing due to health issues.  From here he set himself up as a business man, mostly selling cars on the back of his fame.  Flash forward to 1966 and Henry Ford II has set his sites on beating Ferrari at the Le Mans race of that year, something that Ford has never achieved.  Carroll Shelby is tasked with finding the car, engineers and driver to help him achieve this.  In steps British race car driver Ken Miles, a genius behind the wheel but blunt, reckless and lacking finesse in his private life, an image that Ford feels does not fit with the Ford brand.  From here Shelby and Miles fight against corporate interference to provide the win they know they have the power and skill to achieve.

All of the cast provide great support and fit their roles well but Bale becomes Miles without a doubt, he brings the man alive and is entertaining throughout.  A fun, fast paced and ultimately tragic movie that will keep you entertained for it's considerable running time.

"Logan" and "Walk The Line" director James Mangold reteams with his "3:10 To Yuma" star Christian Bale for "Ford v Ferrari," an easy shoe-in for most deceptive title of the year, as this isn't really a movie about the pride of one man in Detroit, Michigan and another in Modena, Italy, nor is it even really about cars. This is an effective, thrilling, intuitive and enjoyable dissertation on perseverance, friendship, and the neverending battle between creativity and big business, featuring two dynamite performances from both Bale and Matt Damon. Yes, it's a tad safe, and it does tend to play a little loose with certain aspects of truth. However, if I'm being honest, I'm not necessarily sure there's a dire upshot in smoothing over a few edges here and there, especially in a story that bears little to no impact on current circumstances, events, or political movements. It's not as though this is a biopic of one of modern society's formative figures, or even an allegorical exploration into the underpinnings of some of today's issues. We're talking about the difference between cheating during the Super Bowl and cheating in a game of Jenga. That's not to say this movie bears no weight of any kind, though, as all forms of technicality on display (i.e. sound design/mixing, cinematography, stunt work, etc.) help remind you that this at times a life or death pursuit. I'm no expert on automobiles, but I do know a bit about film. And this one's more than worthy of a spin. What a ride.

Ford v Ferrari is the epitome of a crowd pleaser. It's hugely entertaining and thankfully smart as well. It might not be a great film, but it does hark back to those Hollywood days when films were put together on the back of a good story and a bunch of interesting characters to draw you in. I'm not really interested in auto racing at all but I was generally enthralled through out most of its running time. This film is the story of the Le Mans 24 Hour race in 1966 and how the Ford Motor Company tried to take on and defeat the almighty Ferrari team. Ford at the time was slumping in sales and the idea was to sex up the brand by beating Ferrari. They actually tired to buy Ferrari, but old man Enzo sold out to FIAT. The two men heading the charge were American Carroll Shelby, played by Matt Damon, who designed the cars after a successful driving career and British driver Ken Miles. Christian Bale plays Miles and he is superb in the role, embracing perfectly the larger than life personality. The film is about power and innovation. There is plenty of testosterone on display with powerful, proud men going head to head. Especially in the climactic racing scenes. They are filmed with great execution too. The film is probably a little long and some of the characters are a little two dimensional. Especially the Ford Motor executives. But overall this is smart big screen entertainment that gives you value for money.

​It is time to put on your racing gear and drive as fast as you think the producers of this movie would like you too for two and one half hours of pure movie entertainment at its highest levels of writing, acting and directing. This is a really special movie that gear heads and enthusiasts of multiple disciplines will share and enjoy. This is the story of one of the world's most challenging and discipline requiring automobile races that had been dominated by the Ferrari Racing Team almost since its inception. The year is 1966. The race is The 24 Hours of Le Mans in France.
The story is a true to life character depiction of what happens when men who might be best identified as Racing Savants - men who were exceptional visionaries in the field of automobile racing - become involved with a corporate world where image is more important then content and skill is subservient to corporate status. This is the story of Carroll Shelby (played brilliantly by Matt Damon), initially of auto racing fame and later as one of the leading designers of vehicles that were extraordinary in performance and reliability. It is also the story of his long time friend and protege, Ken Miles ( another very special performance by Academy Award winner Christian Bale) as a race car driver whose intensity becomes the greatest challenge this partnership must overcome in their effort to defeat Team Ferrari at Le Mans. The always present corporate involvement of both the Senior Ford and Ferrari Motor Car Company management teams will add a dimension of reality to a program where instinct and a racers primal commitment to winning must coexist if success is to be achieved. This is a movie that all will want to see and all will share in the drama of what it takes to be "The Best in The World" in a sport where life and death are your constant companions.
Rating: M - S - T - A = Must See To Appreciate

For forty years I heard my father tell me stories about Carroll Shelby, Lee Iacocca, Henry Ford II and the GT-40 program. How they built the amazing GT40 and took it to France to kick ol' Enzo's tail on his turf. Over the years I did a little research here and there and found this story to always be fascinating!! And then someone got the grand idea to make it into a movie!!  I HAD to go see it!! And it was absolutely worth EVERY PENNY to see it in IMAX!!!

The sights were incredible!! The sounds even more so!!

Matt Damon did a great job bringing Carroll Shelby to life and Christian Bale executed the role of Ken Miles flawlessly. The driving scenes were fantastic, and the cinematography was second to none. Camera placement was perfect!! Track scenes felt extremely realistic and the incorporation of vintage film scattered throughout really brought this 2019 movie back to the 1960's - while bringing the 1960's into 2019!

But the REAL prize comes through in the soundtrack!! My hat is totally off to the sound engineers!! Is there anything better than a 427 Cubic Inch Big Block Ford spinning at 7000+ RPM on the high banks of Daytona?? Or the 48 valves of a 5 liter Ferrari V-12 doing the same down the Mulsanne Straight in France?? (Hint...The correct answer is no...There definitely isn't!!) From personal experience as someone who grew up with those sounds in real life, the sound editors hit the nail SQUARELY on the head!! (My father was a 427 engine builder. I remember the house shaking when one of those beasts started up in the garage!! He actually worked as a 427 engine builder for Holman & Moody - another GT-40 team that was represented in the movie.) The immersive sound reproduction of the IMAX experience was well worth it!! The engineer should get an Oscar for best Soundtrack for this movie!

If you're a car junkie, this is an ABSOLUTE MUST SEE MOVIE!! I promise I will be seeing it in theaters again soon!! And probably in IMAX too!

Ford v Ferrari is one of those few movies based on well-made real events, which means that most of these types of movies concentrate more on telling the event that happened and completely forget about telling a good story based on facts. real with interesting characters, funny moments, visually entertaining scenes, etc.
And that is exactly why Ford v Ferrari is such a good movie, it does all of the above and more, and all that is topped off with the incredible performances of Christian Bale and Matt Damon and the chemistry they manage to do between the two.
  The film does not lack action or humor, both are perfectly leveled, humor is not silly this is introduced in a good way, something that other films of this genre do not understand, in real life there are comic moments, people laughs, not because it is a film based on real events means that there can be no comedy, of course it can as long as it is within reason, just as the action is great, neither more nor less is not forced or anything like that, and those would be the main elements that make the film visually attractive.
The film does well not to put the protagonists aside, it gives the characters a touch of personality which makes them interesting, while telling their story, but let's be honest the real protagonist is Ken Miles (Christian Bale) because the film focuses more on his personal life, than that of Carroll Shelvy (Matt Damon), since it sets him the goal of overcoming himself physically and psychologically, and Ken is a true race driver, to hell with Dominic Toretto I want Ken Miles.
 But despite all that the character of Matt Damon is not far behind he also tries to overcome either because of his health problems overcome that he will not be able to compete anymore, and building a car faster than those of Ferrari at any cost.
The film did well by not showing Ferrari as an evil company to win, it is only a battle of companies, even when Ken wins the race at the end Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone) shows his respect, one competes against another not because one is good and the other bad, but because of what all companies want money, they want to have the best product to sell, although we support Ford not because they are good or something, but by perspective, we support Ford because the protagonists are with Ford, we would support Ferrari if the protagonists were with Ferrari, in fact the closest to being a villain in this movie would be Leo Bee (Josh Lucas) who is on the side of Ford, and I say the closest because it really is not bad within reason, he just has personal problems with Ken, he doesn't like it, he doesn't want it.
  And speaking of Ken, I loved his death, I say it moved me, but I say I liked it because it was a great element added to the movie, I think this because it was not something that was removed from the sleeve, the problem of the brakes and of not being able to get out of the car, it had already been used previously in the film, which gives a great touch to Ken's death, it happened once I managed to survive, another happened but this time he wasnt so lucky,
The address, although it is not the best in the world, is great, there are several scenes that I can't think of as they were recorded, obviously if there were one with another with special effects, but in other words it is the best part of Mangold.
Actually the only complaint I have to this movie would be Lee Iacocca (Jon Bernthal) is not that I did not like the character on the contrary I like it, but the problem is that in the first act you are introduced as 3rd protagonist, but As the film progresses, it loses prominence, taking away its place of 3rd protagonist.
In conclusion Ford v Ferrari is one of the best movies of 2019, which I really think should be nominated for best film, with a good story, interesting characters, epic moments, great performances, a great direction from Goldman and apart from its best movie, I think this movie is a good 9/10.

I saw this film on Friday night and I loved it. 
It starts during the production company logos and credits before the movie gets going as you hear racing engines roaring.  Then you see things from Carroll Shelby's point of view it sets the mood and a bit of foreshadowing of what's to come. 
Matt Damon and Christian Bale each give earthy performances that harken back to Redford and Newman. I could easily see them in a remake of Butch and Sundance after this film. But, why wouldnt anyone want to do that? 
Damon carries himself like the Texan that Carroll Shelby was, with swagger and a convincing edge that made me believe he was who he told me he was. I can say almost the same thing for Bale, who was at his best and he drew me into Miles truth about his passion for cars and his family. 
Both actors portrayed the men they inhabited with the same kind of passion that Shelby and Miles, at least as the film tells it, live their lives. 
I give Ford v. Ferrari 5 stars out of 5. If I were in the Motion Picture Academy I'd vote Ford v. Ferrari Best Picture because it did what a story is supposed to do and it did in several different ways. 
Ford v. Ferrari created strong emotional responses in me. It made me care about the characters and their stories. From the Opening scene with Matt Damon as Carroll Shelby in a car on the road track in La Mons to poignant tentative wave Shelby gives to Miles wife at the end, I cared about these two people and the Miles family. The fact that Shelby and Miles were real-life people makes, what they have accomplished with Ford v. Ferrari, it that much more impressive to me. 
It is witty, poignant, sad, and inspiring, all in an exciting and thoughtful way. 
I think Ford v. Ferrari is an all-time great film and could arguably go down as the greatest movie ever made, IMHO.

I have anticipated viewing this film for months now, I waited patiently and saw every trailer multiple times, I wanted this movie to be so good, and this movie has exceeded my high expectation, much to my pleasure. I really don't know squat about cars, nor have I ever read or even heard about the feud between Ford and Ferrari in the late '60s, but I loved this movie so much, it makes me want to look up and read the entire real-life story, It was so captivating and intriguing. This movie is never boring and never drags, it is consistently entertaining and surprisingly hilarious, I laughed way more than I thought I would, and jokes are actually very funny. Christian Bale is amazing, the best performance I have seen of his (I haven't seen American Pshyco or The Fighter) and he is so good. He is British racer Ken Miles and he uses his native accent and I loved it, he is funny and still able to be understood. His character is very likable and has a ton of heart, he is grounded and very realistic, he has his own problems and you see them, he also spends a lot of time with his son in this movie, their relationship is explored beautifully and in such a way that it invests us emotionally to Bale's character. Matt Damon is equally as funny and likable, and he gives a great performance as Carroll Shelby. I found him to be caring and he and Bale had such great chemistry together, I thoroughly enjoyed every second they were on the screen with each other, their wrestling scene was comedy gold, it was funny and it also showed how close those two were to each other, it's exactly the type of thing that I want two actors of their caliber to do when they are in the same movie. Caitriona Balfe, who I didn't know before this movie, was excellent, she was so good at her supporting role in this film, she is loving and sweet and feels like a real mother. I found her to be relevant to the plot and extremely effective in her scenes, she was committed and it paid off big time. The scene where she was street racing to get the truth out of Ken was very well done, it was wonderfully acted, it had tons of tension, and it contributed to the relationship of these two characters, it was enthralling. Jon Bernthal was great as well, he was Iacocca, who played a huge part in the real event, a businessman who wanted to help Ford win fairly; he was relevant, and he contributed to the plot very nicely, he is a great actor and I would like to see him in more movies. Josh Lucas played a real douche in this movie, but he was very well acted and you never really felt like you hated him, you see he is greedy and wants to get money any way that he can, but you can sympathize with him because of the desperate situation that Ford was in at the time. Ray Mckinnon was another very good supporting cast member, he really fit the veteran motorhead type who wanted to help younger people find success with cars, he was used nicely in this film. Noah Jupe is turning out to be one of the best child actors in Hollywood, first, it was Wonder, then A Quiet Place, and now this, he is really making a name for himself in some really great movies. He was very realistic and had a sweet relationship with Bale that blossoms during the course of this film, I loved him in this. Every supporting actor and actress in this film was amazing and that is something we rarely see nowadays, the acting in this film is top-notch and I would hope that the academy recognizes that. The racing sequences in this film are spectacular, James Mangold knew exactly how it should be done, we get close-ups every time the car is shifted, we get nice long wide shots that pan over and show us exactly what is going on, and we get to hear out loud what the racer is thinking, I know that I really felt like I was sitting in the shotgun seat right next to him experiencing it, I couldn't be more impressed with how it turned out. As with any film there some flaws, but I only have a couple of them; Jon Bernthal, who I loved in this movie, sort of disappears during the entire third act, most of this act is the Le Mans race and he didn't contribute much there, but we could've seen him in the pits or after the race, I really missed him and wish that he got more screen time. I also thought that Ken Miles death felt very rushed and just a little forced, I know that's what happened in real life so they had to do it, but they could've shown the impact of it a little more, it felt a little bit tacked on because the movie felt no desire to kill him. I loved the length of this movie, it is two and a half hours and I never once felt bored, I was constantly laughing and admiring the amazing craft on display. I also appreciate that anyone could watch this, you don't have to know about or even like cars to enjoy it, and they explain things non-motorheads wouldn't know very naturally and clearly, it never felt like they thought we were stupid or that they had to talk down to us about it, It all flowed very nicely. This is the kind of movie Hollywood rarely makes these days. You know, that classic David vs. Goliath style that many audiences find inspirational. It's wrapped up in a different package, but at its heart it's still one of those underdog feel good movies that general audiences tend to love. The exceptional acting talent sure does help elevate it above similar tales… as well as the brisk directing style that made those 2 ½ hours seem to zip by. I also appreciate the fact that the story itself takes center stage— there are no in your face politically correct narratives and social justice agendas that only serve to muddle up a perfectly good story. I wasn't aware of the events that transpired during the Le Mans race in 1966, and I think going in blindly made the movie more compelling to me. Even people who don't know anything about cars would appreciate this movie. It's a massive crowd-pleaser, and in our movie theater everyone was understandably cheering near the end.

Ford v. Ferarri is the first real blockbuster level racing movie we've had in some time. This is because the subject can get boring in a hurry for non race fans if handled poorly. This is certainly not the case here as the star powered, sharp direction keeps us moving along the entire way.

When a sluggish 1960s American car market, and a business deal gone bad, pin the classic American car manufacturer against it's faster and more stylish Italian counter-part, it's up to car designer, Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) and his reckless driver, Ken Miles (Christian Bale), to deliver a victory in the 24 hour LeMans race in France. Along the way, they'll discover that the infighting inside of their own company is almost as fierce as the competition on the track.

Damon and Bale play off each other really well, and Jon Bernthal (The Punisher), puts in a great third performance as Lee Iacocca, but the real star here is Director James Mangold (Logan), who puts us in the car with Bale during some awesome race scenes, while delivering some great shots of the tracks where our story plays out. The narrative also ensures we love our heroes and despise their rivals, while staying true to it's racing action.

At just over two and a half hours, the film, like the cars it features is a little heavy at times, catching some drag in the process. The film speeds past a perfect ending to give us 20 more minutes we could have done without.

Ford v. Ferarri is still a first place finisher and it should get it's share of attention from the award shows early next year as Damon, Bale, and Mangold all put in notable work.

I guess I assumed we'd get more time from the Ferrari perspective, but really it's all about how the Ford Motor Company wanted to show up Ferrari and make the best racing car the world has ever seen (well at least in 1966). Additionally Damon may get top billing but really Bale morphs in our real protagonist between the two if I had to choose - I certainly cared for his character more as we get scenes with himself, his son and his wife frequently. These are minor nitpicks though, Ford v Ferrari is good enough entertainment but I can't see myself rewatching it anytime soon.

FORD V FERRARI-2019(PG-13)-Nov. 15. By:Clem The Movie Guy. Ford V Ferrari is an incredibly intense & compelling true story of how two men were involved in making history for the legendary Ford Motor Company against Enzo Ferrari & his racing team in the iconic 24-hour long race at Le Mans in 1966. Set in 1963, the Ford Company is struggling with car sales. To boost sales, Ford Vice President Lee Iacocca (Jon Bernthal) proposes to Ford owner Henry Ford II (Tracy Letts) that he purchase the cash-strapped Ferrari & start the production of a sporty new Ford that would appeal to a younger generation of drivers. When Ferrari’s owner Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone) refuses the offer in rather insulting terms, a furious Henry II orders his racing team division to build a car, the Ford GT40, in an effort to defeat Ferrari at Le Mans. Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon), a former race driver, forced to retire because of a heart condition after winning the Le Mans in 1959, now runs Shelby Automobiles. He is hired by Lee Iacocca to design the perfect car to hopefully beat Ferrari at Le Mans. Shelby enlists the help of his old friend Ken Miles (Christian Bale), an exceptional although temperamental race car driver struggling to make a living as mechanic. As Shelby & Miles are testing the Ford GT4O MK I prototype, they have worked together to create, Shelby is told by Leo Beebe (Josh Lucas), a Ford executive, that drivers Phil Hill & Bruce McLaren are going to the 64’ Le Mans instead Miles. Feeling humiliated by all the Fords finishing the race, Henry II is told by Shelby that despite the loss, the GT4O has put fear into Ferrari as it reached 218 mph on the Mulsanne straight & was faster than any Ferrari. Henry II tells Shelby to go kick Ferrari’s ass & Shelby & Miles begin testing the GT40 MK II. Shelby tells Ford that if Miles doesn’t drive & win at Le Mans, he will forfeit ownership of Shelby Automobiles. Now with everything on the line, Shelby & Miles ultimately have 24 hours to do the unthinkable by taking down the Ferrari racing team. Ford V Ferrari is directed by James Mangold from the screenplay written by Jez Butterworth, John-Henry Butterworth, & Jason Keller. Ford V Ferrari is a true underdog story of overcoming personal demons, corporate meddling, & fierce competition. The race scenes were riveting. The performances from the cast were excellent. I wouldn’t be surprised to see Ford V Ferrari getting some award consideration. Ford V Ferrari is a MUST-SEE FILM for those who are car-lovers & anyone who wants to learn about the war between these two major car manufacturers & the iconic race that redefined them.

This was a lot better than I thought it was going to be although I had some issues that held this film from being really good. The first 30-45 minutes were just uninteresting to me. It was well acted but there was nothing that was keeping me interested. Once we get to the point where they are modifying the car, it gets pretty great. Christian Bale and Matt Damon do great jobs but Bale steals the show. Bale is perfectly cast and is fantastic as this angry race car driver. Both Damon and Bale have perfect chemistry and play off well with each other thanks to a pretty good script although not a perfect one. Most of the other actors did a pretty good job also. There is also some good chemistry between Bale and Noah Jupe who plays Bale's son. They also have some genuinely touching moments together. The only character I didn't like was Jon Bernthal's character. I thought he was extremely one dimensional and irritating. I thought the racing sequences in the film were fantastic. They are incredibly well shot and paced. Even though the film is based on true events, I still felt exhilarated and was on the edge of my seat. The Le Mans sequence was one of the best sequences in film that I saw so far this year. The sound mixing is pretty great also. It immerses you within the races which makes those sequences so much better. I felt the last 10 minutes of the film was pointless. I thought the film was gonna end after this desert scene that I won't spoil but it kept going on. The music was also pretty bland. Even after just seeing the film, I don't remember any of the music. Some of the other technical aspects that I liked was the cinematography. During the racing scenes, it was great and during the rest of the film, it was pretty good. The film has a couple visual effects scenes that I thought looked pretty good. Overall, Ford v Ferrari is a pretty good film with great racing sequences, great acting, and some good cinematography even if the first 30 minutes and last 10 minutes were generally uninteresting.

Showdown in France.  So in the 1960s, the Ford Motor Company decided that in addition to pumping out car after car on the assembly line, they wanted to develop a racecar that could beat Ferrari at Le Mans, which is the French city home to an annual race that lasts for 24 hours straight.  To make this happen, they have to put together not only the right vehicle but also the right team.  Now I may not be a huge fan of racing as a sport, but I do go wild for a good racing movie.  If you can put together a well-made film that can get my pulse pounding with cars going excessively fast, I'm going to absolutely be in your corner.  The trailers looked terrific, so I went into this just wanting something that is comparable to 2013's Rush, and while this is not Formula One, it is just as good in quality.  Now, this is directed by James Mangold, and while he may not be the first name you think of during award season, he's not exactly a lightweight.  He has put out some damn fine movies throughout the years, and he most certainly knows how to work with Christian Bale, who turns out yet another terrific performance as the crusty mechanic/racer savant Ken Miles.  He purposely rubs people the wrong way, so even though he is unparalleled in his field, you can 100% understand why people have it out for him.  So much of this is the relationship between him and Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon).  Because Shelby is the only one that can see past that difficult personality to the raw talent, he is the only one who knows that Miles is the right person for the job.  What I appreciate the most about Ford v Ferrari is that it takes time to build characters.  Racing is almost secondary until you get to the last hour, and let me tell you something; this is a two and a half hour movie.  I know long runtimes tend to steer audiences away, but I'm hoping that doesn't deter here because this is probably the fastest moving 150 minutes you're going to see all year.  You get a full movie filled with great performances, funny dialogue and good pacing, and then it tops everything off with two really well-executed races.  By that point, you care about these people, so you are invested in the outcome of how these cars finish.  Everybody loves a good underdog story, and this has underdogs within the overarching underdog story.  It works as a period piece and the racing is as exciting as can be; it is shot in such a way that you feel like you are right there on the track, and you can always tell exactly what is going on.  These are roles that are fun for everyone to play, and the jokes land every time comedic relief is called for.  If this movie ever pops up when I'm flipping through channels in a year or so, I will probably slip in and watch the whole movie.  Go check this out, you won't regret it.

A great little bio pic about how Ford entered into the world of international racing by building the legendary Ford GT40 to compete with Ferrari during the 24 hours Le Mans race in France. The movie opens with Ford trying to actually purchase Ferrari (who recently had just gone bankrupt), but Ferrari backs out when Fiat gives a much better deal. Realizing that Ferrari never intended for Ford to buy them and had just used them to get more money from Fiat, Henry Ford II (Tracy Letts) instructs his inner circle to find the best engineers and designers to make a car that will beat Ferrari. In comes Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon). Shelby owns Shelby America who makes custom cars as well as competes in smaller races. Shelby himself is the only American to ever win the Le Mans several years back, but had to quit because of a heart condition. Shelby signs on and brings with him the best driver he has Ken Miles (Christian Bale). Ken is kind of a wild guy that is very much a talented driver, but has a very strong opinion of just about everything. He's not really the ideal "Ford" driver and therefore clashes with the suits in charge of Ford. Together Shelby and Ken have to somehow overcome the suits of Ford picking at everything and still develop the best car the worlds ever seen. So, yeah I liked this one a lot. The movie has a cool story and although I knew the outcome already ahead of time I enjoyed how it's told. The characters are interesting and the two leads in Damon and Bale do a great job here. The racing scenes are really well done as well. It creates very high tension moments and it seems like a lot was done practically. I will say the movie is very long at 2 and a half hours long, but I enjoyed the pacing and didn't think it was slow at any time. The film is a great story and I liked especially how it's not just a movie that is glorifying Ford. It shows that Ford and Ferrari are both companies and have money and fame on the mind. Ford itself seems to only be doing it because they feel embarrassed, but Henry Ford II seems like a joke. While Ferrari is in it because of the passion of racing and their own pride. The main focus here is Miles and Shelby and it succeeds in that. I would highly recommend checking this one out!

Racing could be considered an art form in the same vein as movies. And Hollywood has taken notice. Over the past century, Hollywood has managed to churn out quite a lot of films with the subject of racing being involved. And one of the newer films to feature racing in a rather addicting entertainment form, is "Ford v Ferrari", the historical feature about how the Ford Motor Company built a car fast enough to beat Ferrari at the famous Le Mans raceway. Directed by James Mangold, and starring Matt Damon and Christian Bale, the film explores the lives of two professional car enthusiasts, who want to earn that fame and glory alongside Ford. While there are some factual errors as this is a film, they are only minor, ad the rest of the film is a great and amazing thrill ride; especially for the ears. "Ford v Ferrari" is a movie that only people who enjoy cars and racing will enjoy.

The story focuses on two very different individuals: Carroll Shelby (Damon), and Ken Miles (Bale). Shelby is a former racer that now sells racecars to the general public. Shelby is a mechanic going through some financial difficulties. Shelby gets approached by the Ford Motor Company to build him a car to beat Ferrari at Le Mans, With the help of Miles, Carroll and Ken decide to make racing history by proving that the Americans are better racers than the Italians.

"Ford v Ferrari" is a great and spectacular film.

The story is engaging, and keeps the viewer interested throughout is nearly two and a half hour run time. Everything that happens on the screen is fascinating, This is all thanks to the editing by three individuals: Andrew Buckland, Michael McCusker, and Dirk Westervelt. These three guys managed to create a truly exciting film for people to view.

The cinematography by Phedon Papamichael looks absolutely amazing. The movie looks like it was from the 1960s, and it feels like the 1960s. Phedon did a really great job making this movie look good.

What really sells this film is the sound. Everything, from the sound mixing and sound editing, is really perfected here. All of the mechanics and noises are heard. And the racing. Every little detail that goes into the racing is implemented here. It feels like one is actually in the car while the driving is taking place.

The cast is great as well. Both Damon and Bale deliver great performances. But it is Bale who truly shines. He may not get top billing, but this is definitely one of his best performances ever.

Finally, the direction by Mangold is absolutely stunning. He manages to create a great deal of tension between the characters presented here. And all of the scenes are blocked perfectly. Plus, Mangold directs the actors with sense of realism, and there is a sense of friendship being delivered within their performances. Mangold is truly rising up to become one of the best directors of all time.

The only criticism that the film brings up is with its history. Yes, this is a work of fiction, but a lot of the stuff presented here is fictionalized. But this the only major criticism that I found while watching the film.

In conclusion, "Ford v Ferrari" is a racing fan's dream come true, and will definitely bring out a lot enjoyment from anyone who enjoys a little fast speed with their entertainment. Step on the gas, and see this movie for yourself.

The definition of “idyllic” is spending childhood summers in the 1950s and 60s at a small Sierra Nevada logging town in the remote outskirts of Fresno County. Unless I wanted to spend three months swimming, fishing, building forts and roasting marshmallows by myself, whoever emerged from the cabins scattered around the mill were my new best friends. And those best friends were all boys from Central Valley towns where car racing reigned supreme, mostly NASCAR but formula, drag, off-road, touring, sports—if it involved four wheels, it commanded attention. Add in stacks of Motor Sports magazines and raging Ford vs Chevy arguments while passing greasy wrenches back and forth, tinkering with a Willys Jeep and you have a good flavor of mill life. Watching Ford v Ferrari was a throwback to those times. I could practically feel the grease and smell the burnt rubber! A life lesson on power and the powerful unfolds as we sit, students of history watching two international titans clash, America’s proud yet ruthless Henry Ford (Tracy Letts) taking on Italy’s regal yet derisive Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone). Two renown automakers stake their brand and their reputation on winning Le Mans, a 24 hour contest for man and machine, the “Grand Prix of Endurance and Efficiency.” In 1966 it becomes the ultimate match race between perennial winner Ferrari and upstart competitor Ford. Loyalty and brotherhood, treachery and deceit, it’s all there. Win. Just win. Shifting Team Ford into high gear is talented, passionate, straight-shooting expert car designer Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) always strutting around in his black cowboy hat, matched with cocky, hotheaded, confident, driver par excellence Ken Miles (Christian Bale), forming an entrepreneurial and fearless duet who, curiously enough, are making their first paired film debut in this rip-roaring true story. The Shelby/Miles bromance works perfectly in ratcheting up drama interspersed with comedic exchanges including a hilarious fistfight that so amuses Ken’s wife Mollie (Caitriona Balfe) that she unfolds a chair to better watch them roll around on the lawn, until she graciously fetches them cold sodas while they catch their breath lying side by side in the yard. The chemistry between Damon and Bale hold the movie together from the starting gun through the checkered flag. Their on screen relationship, although tumultuous at times, is deeply defined by mutual respect. Two mere mortals, one Brit, one American, share rare membership in the elite “perfect lap” club, who understand 7,000 RPMS as a spiritual experience. “There’s a point at 7,000 RPMs where everything fades. The machine becomes weightless. It disappears. All that’s left, a body moving through space, and time. At 7,000 RPM, that’s where you meet it. That’s where it waits for you.” The film runs long at 2 1/2 hours and could have been shortened while not losing a beat by cutting out Mollie and Ken’s young son, Peter (Noah Jupe). Their roles are undeveloped and unnecessary to plot development. Carroll and Ken offer enough of the family feel. Ford Company executives Lee Iacocca (Jon Bernthal) and Leo Beebe (Josh Lucas) try to muscle in between Carroll and Miles to no avail. The Iacocca role holds up as an insider ally to Carroll but Beebe as the story’s contemptuous villain is a loss leader to nowhere. He can go. Men dominate the screen at least 98% of the time reflecting the industry and era. Probably still holds true. The racing sequences drop you directly into the drivers seat at track level with thundering decibels and breathtaking speeds. When I drove away from the theater I revved my 4 cylinder Honda into high gear and blew right past a Toyota! The thrill of victory and all that heady stuff. Ford v Ferrari is an instant classic. If you are a racing fan, you’ll love the energy of this film. If you are a connoisseur of cinematography, you’ll enjoy the technical savvy. If you are an observer of human behavior, you’ll appreciate the intuitive depth. Ford v Ferrari may be the racing movie equivalent of the perfect lap. As Ken Miles asks, “Do you see it?” Seeing this movie may be the closest way of answering yes

Superb chronicle of the class Ford vs. Ferrari rivalry during the 1960's Le Mans, thanks to expert direction and a top notch cast.  The actors are superb across the board, with the two leads: Matt Damon & Christian Bale, giving some of the best performances of their careers.  The scene stealer, though, is Tracy Letts as Henry Ford II, a hardened business mogul who at his core, wants to produce a truly great car.  Behind the camera, director James Manigold delivers an epic but surprising fast paced story (despite being 2 and half hours, it never drags) with some great racing sequences and human drama.  Most interesting is how the creates a conflict, as the film is essentially about two rival car company's, by focusing on the mechanics and drivers who made it possible.  The end result is one of the best and most entertaining movies this year, and one I fully expect to be represented at Oscar season.
