Do you remember a time when movies were fun? The rush of excitement during the film’s climax, the bitter-sweet tears of an emotional conclusion, the laughs of a well-setup joke? You get out of your seat, use the bathroom, get to your car, and talk endlessly with your movie-mate about all the great things you just watched? That’s what I experienced this last weekend at the Ford v Ferrari IMAX showing. 

Ford v Ferrari is directed by James Mangold (Walk the Line, Logan), and it stars Matt Damon (Bourne Series) and Christian Bale (Dark Knight series). The film is based on the real story of the Ford Motor Company, headed by Henry Ford II, looking to beat the sales of the seemingly unstoppable General Motors. He tells his workers to come to him with an idea, or don’t come back to work. Ford’s Marketing Manager Lee Iacocca, played by Jon Bernthal (Netflix’s Punisher, The Walking Dead), says that sales are determined by which company wins the biggest races. His idea? To beat the unbeatable Ferrari in the biggest race in the world, The 24 Hours of Le Mans. Iacocca enlists one of the only Americans to win the race, Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon), to build him a car. Shelby tells Iacocca that it takes more than speed it takes a good driver. Shelby then recruits his longtime racing associate Ken Miles (Christian Bale) to help build and test the car for him since Shelby can’t race due to health reasons. What follows is a battle of science, speed, and corporate intervention where all roads lead to the 24 Hour endurance test at Le Mans. Will Shelby risk his entire livelihood on one driver, and will Miles prove his worth to his family and the world?

What I immediately loved about this movie is its cinematography. It looks, sounds, and feels like a 1960’s garage. You can practically smell the oil and grease. I’m not necessarily a car guy. I love a beautiful car like any other person, and the revving of an engine is awesome, but I don’t care what type of engine it is or what shape of headlight came with what model. What might turn a few people away is the almost three-hour run time. Did I have to take multiple restroom breaks? Yes. Did the movie feel like three hours? No. The fast-paced dialogue and action set a nice pace that never felt like a chore to sit through. 

We sat down dead center in the IMAX Theater, popcorn and sodas in hand. From the opening logos, you hear the roaring of engines, and then a hard cut of a first person perspective of a car zooming down a dark rain-covered road with headlights illuminating only a few feet ahead. Immediately I was blown away by the loud rich sound of the IMAX speakers putting you into the driver’s seat. Every time an engine revved and a tire screeched, it was glorious and made your heart race. For the sound design alone, this is a must-own. But what makes this movie unique from others in its genre is the characters and realism. Movies like the Fast and the Furious series focus on spectacle and explosions, hot girls, exotic cars, contemporary music. Ford v Ferrari uses visual and audio aesthetics of 1960’s America to place you in that time period without using tired conventional methods (Rolling Stones music anyone?). There’s almost no 60’s music here, only original score, which works in the movie’s favor. Too many times do we see period movies focus too much on reminding you which era you’re in instead of just telling the story. Thankfully, Mangold is a great storyteller.

What really stands out here is the acting. Everyone here nails their performance. The standout being Bale as Miles. Once again he transformed his body after gaining a ton of weight to play Dick Cheney in Vice, and lost it all to play Miles. He claims he’s done doing that, but we’ll have to see. His relationship with the Ford Corporation and his wife and kid are what tug on your heartstrings. He’s so likable all you want is to see him succeed. His pure passion for driving is what brings this movie its fun factor.  He perfectly plays off of Damon’s dry southern humor and you can tell Miles loves cars and speed. All he wants is to prove he’s the one to win Le Mans. Damon does a great job portraying Shelby, and his arc is the one that drives the relationship between Miles and the suites at Ford.

You don’t have to be a car nut to enjoy this film. Same reason you don’t have to be a chef to love the taste of fine dining. It has fun with the source material and leaves you with a smile on your face during the credits. I think the standout here is Bale and awards will surely be coming his way. Is it a little long? Sure, but you're so enthralled with the action that you never think about looking at your watch.

After the huge success of ‘Logan’, James Mangold goes back in time to the Le Mans ‘66 for ‘Ford v Ferrari’. American car designer Carroll Shelby and driver Ken Miles battle corporate interference, the laws of physics and their own personal demons to build a revolutionary race car for Ford and challenge Ferrari at the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1966. First of all, Matt Damon and Christian Bale sharing the big screen together makes the movie itself so funny and exhilarating. They really have great chemistry. The film is 2hr 32min, credits included. You will not feel its runtime; the film’s editing and pacing is so good, thanks to Mangold’s directing, screenwriting, and editor’s Andrew Buckland, Michael McCusker, and Dirk Westervelt. The editing is very Oscar-worthy and so is the film’s sound design and Bale’s performance. The racing sequences are really one of the film’s most fun with the beautiful shots by cinematographer Phedon Papamichael. Also, I can’t wait to listen to Marco Beltrami & Buck Sanders’ musical score, it’s really good (particularly, during the climactic Le Mans race). Like I said, Bale’s performance, editing, and sound design are definitely Oscar-worthy. This is another big win for director James Mangold. One of the best movies of 2019! 8.2/10.

Ford v. Ferrari is a retelling of the Ford company's attempts to compete with Ferrari in building racing cars and win the Le Mans race and the designer and driver behind getting the tasks done. This is just a really well put together, well written movie that looks at the passion for something in contrast with the constraints of the business world.

The direction on this is tight. It looks nice and the pacing is pretty smooth for a two-and-a-half hour movie. Director James Mangold (Logan, Walk the Line) really knows how to make scenes visually interesting, throwing in little stuff. Though there isn't really that much racing in this, the race at Le Mans really pays off your expectations.

Matt Damon and Christian Bale are the leads in this, the former being the guy who tries to work within the system and the latter being the guy who can't. Matt Damon gives a fine performance, but it's Bale who steals every scene he's in. The famously versatile actor completely sells the character of driver Ken Miles, both brash but charismatic. I'll be very surprised if he doesn't get an Oscar nomination. To be honest, the casting even to the smallest characters is pretty darn good. Props should be given to Tracy Letts as tough, intimidating boss Henry Ford II.

The only weak spot I found, and it's more of a knitpick, is that they could've cut down on the scenes of Miles interacting with his family. It's good stuff, but it can be a little repetitive.

Overall, I highly recommend this.

Ford V Ferrari is a pure adrenaline rush from start to finish. It's an absolutely thrilling film that fires on all cylinders.

Ferrari dominates the annual 24-hour race at Le Mans for much of the 1960s. Ford decides to throw their hat in the ring, in hopes that a victory at Le Mans will raise their struggling sales. The former racer turned car designer Carrol Shelby (Matt Damon) and his difficult, but passionate racer pal Ken Miles (Christian Bale) are both brought on to help Ford craft a car to get to the finish line.

Beneath the technical polish and gloss of Ford V Ferrari, the friendship between Shelby and Miles is the heart of the film. Christian Bale and Matt Damon are a large part of what makes this film work so well. This is their first movie together and yet, they interact with the ease of old friends. Their performances complement each other. You get really invested in this on-screen duo with an absurd amount of charm exuding from the screen.

We all love a good underdog and this film is a classic underdog story. Ford V Ferrari isn't just about the race at Le Mans, but more about the human struggles encountered to get there. Pride and jealousy constrict Miles and Shelby at times, but the rigid corporate system of Ford Motor Company poses a greater challenge. Ford V Ferrari is an expansive, mesmerizing real-life story that feels perfect for the cinematic medium.

Ford V Ferrari puts you in the driver's seat with the racers, but not in the way I was expecting. The stellar sound design and mixing are some of the best and extremely transportive. They give the racing sequences not just an immersive quality, but a transcendent one. James Mangold's direction is excellent. He gives you sequences that put you on the edge of your seat and capture your gaze. More so, Mangold has a strong grasp on pacing. The film knows when to slow down and emphasize character and emotion and when to boost its engine and hightail it to the next scene. In a film this long, it's remarkable that it feels as breezy as it does. Even if you know this story start to finish, the skill, technically and narrative in which it's told make this ride one easily worth taking.

I recommend Ford V Ferrari for ages 7 to 14 for language. Even if you're not a race car fanatic, there's a good chance you'll love this film. I happily give it 5 out of 5 stars. This is easily one of my favorites of the year.

Christian Bale's newest acting transformation shocks by not shocking this time around as the English actor retains a natural physical look and instead captures Miles' character from the inside out. Miles' love for the sport, and more notably his family comes across marvelously through Bale's performance, especially when in conjunction to his onscreen family of Noah Jupe and the excellent supporting Caitriona Balfe. Though Matt Damon also does a solid job as Shelby alongside a good secondary cast, it's Bale's performance that elevates the film with a greater emotional resonance.

Mangold also cranks up what's otherwise a fairly standard sports underdog movie with a visceral directing style that does the vicious rush of the racing track exhilarating justice. With blaring sound design and Mangold's heart-pounding cinematic vision relentlessly pushing eleven, the line between athletic glory and life-ending disaster furiously oscillates without ever letting up—I was consistently hitting the brakes of my imaginary car throughout my screening of the film.

I don't care one lick about cars and I was greatly entertained by Ford vs. Ferrari, a thrilling look back where the gear-heads at Ford wanted to build a new model of racing car that could challenge the seemingly unbeatable Italians at the Le Mans raceway. The smartest move the movie makes is placing this as a character-driven story with a group of big personalities solving a puzzle and trying to prove the arrogant suits wrong. It has such winning elements that it's got crowd-pleaser DNA all over it, even if you'll likely predict every step of the story. Even if you know nothing about the history of racing and motor vehicles, you can suspect that designer Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) and driver Ken Miles (Christian Bale) will, through grit and confidence and outside-the-box thinking, overcome their obstacles to win the 1966 Le Mans race. The movie even realizes this, and that's why the climax of the movie isn't whether or not Ford will triumph but on a very personal dilemma and choice. It's less about the mechanics of cars and more about simply solving problems with innovative solutions, and there's a great satisfaction in watching characters we care about get closer to solving a puzzle that has outwitted the masses. As the characters get excited, we get excited because the personal is what is felt most. Miles is an arrogant, disgraced driver that Ford doesn't want being the face of anything for the company. Shelby is trying to transition from being in a car to the head of a company, and he's the heat shield for his team, taking the corporate ire and laying more and more on the line for their experiments. Damon is great, and sounds uncannily like Tommy Lee Jones, but this is chiefly Bale's movie and he is fantastic. He once again just disappears into a character, this time the lanky, cocky, hard-driving family man, and the scenes with Miles' wife and son actually provide important dimension to all the participants. They aren't simply there to express concern or admiration. The screenplay by the Butterworth brothers (Edge of Tomorrow) and Jason Keller (Machine Gun Preacher) have opened up these characters, their fear, anxieties, hopes, and dreams in a way that feels genuine and considerate. They hook us in with the characters early, so that the rest of the film serves as a series of payoffs for our investment. The racing sequences are thrilling as director James Mangold (Logan) has his camera career around the cars, placing the audience in the middle of the RPMs and feeling that immersive sense of speed. I never knew that the Le Mans race is 24 hours long, and the scene of these 1960s cars, with 1960s windshield wiper technology, driving in the rain and dark at 200 miles-per-hour is starkly terrifying. I still don't care much about cars or their history, but you present me engaging characters and Oscar-caliber performances to boot, and I'll watch those people anywhere. Ford vs. Ferrari is a bit long (150 minutes) but a well-crafted, potent crowd-pleaser with exhilarating racing and strong characters worthy of cheering.

From James Mangold, the director of Logan, comes a biopic based off of the Ford company competing against Ferrari in the 1966 Le Mans race. With a cast like Matt Damon, Christian Bale, Josh Lucas, Jon Bernthal, Caitriona Balfe and a young talent in Noah Jupe, my excitement was at an all time high for this film. I'm happy to say, this was one of the best films I've seen all year. 

I have not had this much fun at a movie in such a long time. I had a smile on my face just about the entire run-time. This is a charming, exciting, and often hilarious story brought to the big screen. Christian Bale may have given his best performance ever as Ken Miles. He has so many hilarious lines of dialogue and the way he delivers them was just the icing on the cake. Matt Damon was also terrific like he usually is and also had some hilarious lines. The racing sequences were just flat out exhilarating to watch and were filmed in some beautiful wide-shots. There was a great father and son relationship dynamic that was established and it really worked and made for a very emotionally satisfying arc throughout the film. I absolutely loved the song choices chosen for this movie. It wasn't the cliche songs we've heard a hundred times in every mediocre film nowadays. The editing was fantastic as well. You have to hand it to the editing crew for really making the race sequences flow naturally and in a way to not confuse viewers as to where the racers are in the race. I also found this movie surprisingly touching in the end. No spoilers of course because I was unaware of the real events and how they turned out but when this film wrapped up, there was definitely an emotional feeling in me. 

I have but one issue in this movie and it's just the pacing in the second act jumps ahead very quickly and unexpectedly. Usually films use title cards when going back to a certain year or date but this film didn't which made it a little confusing for me and it made the movie move a little too fast. 

All in all, I had an absolute blast watching this movie. I cannot wait to see it again and if Bale and Damon aren't nominated for Oscars for this movie, I won't be surprised, but I'll be mad at the same time. Definitely check this one out and I'm going to give Ford v Ferrari, an A

James Mangold has straddled genres rather successfully. He made probably the best X-Men film when the franchise was exhausted and got me enjoying a Western (2007's 3:10 To Yuma), a genre that's nowhere near my favourite; and now, re-teaming with Yuma's Christian Bale, he's done it again with a motor-racing film. Charting the origin of and the events leading up to the titular race that defines the rivalry between Ford and Ferrari (hence its US title), I was surprised as to how engaged and thrilled I was, despite not being part of the Top Gear/sports film crowd it'll indubitably appeal to. Perhaps it's because I'm practically superglued to the edge of my seat watching racing sequences that's executed in a visceral and cinematically intelligent manner, while their sound mixing engineers are surely frontrunners come Oscar time. Or perhaps it's the rather moving and affecting bromantic friendship between American car designer Carroll Shelby (a solid yet charming Matt Damon) and British driver/mechanical genius Ken Miles (in another uniquely immersive performance by Bale, who's English but locked in a battle with an unlocatable English accent here). The 152mins literally flew by for me, aided by Marco Beltrami & Buck Sanders' light and jazzy score that gives it a breezy caper movie feel as we watch Shelby and Miles gallantly fending off the suits from Ford to stay true to their artistry. Co-written by Jez Butterworth, the script is smart and authentic yet remains accessible to an audience unfamiliar with the jargon (even if sometimes dialogue recapping or stating the obvious in case some audience got lost can feel a little jarring). There's no doubt the film is at its most adrenalin-fuelled best during the racing sequences but this slick and technically proficient film also has a big heart beating underneath it all.

I still haven't even seen Days of Thunder so, needless to say, I am probably not the target audience but I am a Michigander and Detroit, Dearborn, and even Ford Motor are all kinda ingrained to my soul.

- 1/2 point(9 1/2 of 10) because no movie is perfect until it convinces me it might be.    

- 1/2 point(9 of 10) because it's just not as good as the one racing movie I truly like and hold in high regard - Rush.

- 1/2 point(8 1/2 of 10) for the title and the way the story is portrayed.  It was titled Ford v Ferrari which implies there is a ‘good guy' and a ‘bad guy' but it was more like Bad Guy vs. The Bad Guy's Bad Guy.'  If you are expecting a movie that casts Ford in a positive light then you will be disappointed.  I left the movie thinking, wow, Ford Motor... what a bunch of stupid assholes.  

- 1/2 point(8 of 10) because there is no one likeable in the movie.  You don't want to see Ferrari win, you don't want to see Ford win, you don't want to see Caroll Shelby win, you don't mind seeing Ken Miles win but... well, I guess you'll just have to see it for yourself.

- 1/2 point(7 1/2 of 10) because I felt the leads were miscast.  Ken Miles was almost as annoying as the cackling hags sitting a few rows up, and both his wife and child could have been featured far less.  This is a very niche story and movie that they tried to make appealing to broader audiences with those other characters, and the big names they cast, and other elements of the story that had a fairly good amount of Hollywood spin on it.    

- 1/2 point(7 of 10) because the final race was a letdown.  I was really expecting more from the race scenes.  If you're expecting a racing movie you will be disappointed.  This is more Tucker: The Man and His Dream than it is Rush.  

- 1/2 point(6 1/2 of 10) for the soundtrack.  At this point I think they're just trolling people.  You think something good is about to start playing in the background to give the film some pop or evoke some emotion but then it just drops straight off a cliff and becomes some lesser known riff.

I did not find this movie enjoyable and probably never will, but... like I said there are elements of it ingrained to the fabric of my being.

James Mangold's "Ford v Ferrari" is a thrilling car-racing drama that is fueled by fantastic performances from Christian Bale and Matt Damon. With his latest feature, Mangold has crafted an exhilarating dramatization of the Le Mans car race. Using gorgeous cinematography, Mangold crafts the most exciting car race sequences of the year. Shot with precision and an eye for detail, the car race sequences are arguably the highlight of the movie. Each sequence keeps viewers wound in a state of suspense and tension. Aside from excelling behind the camera, Mangold draws excellent performances from his leading stars. Christian Bale and Matt Damon are sensational in the lead roles, creating a real-life friendship that feels utterly believable. Bale is one of those actors that commits every ounce of his energy to his roles, and here he proves it. Intense, charismatic and passionate, he excels in the role of a committed race-car driver. Damon, on the other hand, delivers one of the best performances of his career. Charming, comical and witty, he creates a compelling portrait of a real-life businessman. Although "Ford v Ferrari" is undeniably entertaining, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. At nearly two and a half hours, it is really long and suffers from a lengthy running time. Director James Mangold keeps the film moving at an engaging pace, but it does drag at times. For a car racing movie, it takes an unusually long time to get to the finish line. Nevertheless, fans of car racing will definitely enjoy "Ford v Ferrari" and so will movie-goers seeking exhilarating entertainment this fall season. Even if it is slightly long, "Ford v Ferrari" is an immensely enjoyable film that is worth seeing for its car racing sequences alone.

James Mangold's ‘Ford v Ferrari' is a fun two-and-a-half hour ride down memory lane, circling the lives of legendary race car driver Ken Miles and equally esteemed car designer Carroll Shelby.

The film gets off to an uninspiring start, introducing the main characters using quick-hitting scenes that turn each into an eye-rolling archetype.  Shelby is the inspired engineer.  Miles is the irascible wildcard.  Henry Ford II is the cutthroat Man of Industry … and they even give him a sniveling bulldog lackey.

The second half of the film picks up the pace and is considerably more engaging.  Mangold does a fine job filming the racing scenes, choosing just the right balance of different viewpoints and cuts.  Beyond that, he thankfully spares audiences from the awful "shaky camera effect" that some filmmakers would've used anytime they wanted to ramp up the action on screen.

Given that the ‘24 Hours of Le Mans' race is indeed twenty-four hours long, Mangold also excels at keeping an even pace down the final stretch, not relying too much on either the racing or the off track drama, but rather striking an even balance between the two.

Ford v Ferrari is the true story of Carroll Shelby (Matt Damon) and Ken Miles (Christian Bale) and their quest to win Le Mans in 1966 and it's a great ride. Shelby is enlisted by Henry Ford II (Tracy Letts) to create a car that could end the domination of Ferrari at the iconic French 24 hour race. It's a classic ‘mine's bigger than yours' battle he has with Enzo Ferrari (Remo Girone) that's complicated by his efforts to, as Shelby tells him is the wrong way, win a race by committee. Simply put Ford's team of goons doesn't like Miles. The 155 minute running time is a stretch but thankfully it doesn't drag and the film is aided by a masterclass from Bale. This man is a freak of an actor! And the rapport he has with Damon is important. You can see it in the scene where the two scuffle. Great quality film, a good mix of serious and light moments and very enjoyable too. Well worth seeing.
